Expectation1: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation1: A congregant has just passed away and the family needs him to officiate the funeral service very soon.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They are expected at routine meetings that occur frequently
Story: This morning, my phone buzzed with the news that Mrs. Goldstein had passed away. Her family, devastated, asked if I could officiate the funeral service tomorrow. As their rabbi, I know how much it means to them to have me guide them through this moment, to offer comfort and tradition. But as I hung up, my calendar reminded me of the advocacy meeting scheduled at the same time—one of those routine but mandatory sessions where my presence is expected, and my absence is noticed. The advocacy team relies on me to represent our clients, to be punctual and prepared. I feel the weight of both roles pressing down on me: the family’s grief, the community’s expectations, the professional responsibility to my advocacy work. My mind races, torn between honoring a life and fulfilling my duty to those who depend on my advocacy. I sit at my desk, heart pounding, knowing I must choose, but not yet knowing how.
